item.title: By: oldiev
item.dc:creator: oldiev
item.description: Since you require composer installed on a server to install Symfony and other PHP frameworks, I don't think you can do that on shared servers. Because you don't get composer there. I wouldn't recommend shared server anyway because of lack of security and performance issues. A better option is some affordable dedicated server like DigitalOcean, unless you know how to set it up. If you don't have sysadmin experience for that, then you can use Cloudways <a href="https://www.cloudways.com/en/php-cloud-hosting.php" rel="nofollow">PHP MySQL hosting</a> platform where the server is configured automatically and you get managed digitalocean server. You also get composer pre-installed, so you can install any php framework or CMS you want.
item.content:encoded: Since you require composer installed on a server to install Symfony and other PHP frameworks, I don’t think you can do that on shared servers. Because you don’t get composer there. I wouldn’t recommend shared server anyway because of lack of security and performance issues. A better option is some affordable dedicated server like DigitalOcean, unless you know how to set it up. If you don’t have sysadmin experience for that, then you can use Cloudways PHP MySQL hosting platform where the server is configured automatically and you get managed digitalocean server. You also get composer pre-installed, so you can install any php framework or CMS you want.

item.title: By: Problems Hosting Symfony 1.2 (!) sites on Godaddy? « Richtermeister’s Code - Massacre
item.dc:creator: Problems Hosting Symfony 1.2 (!) sites on Godaddy? « Richtermeister’s Code - Massacre
item.description: [...] Addendum: Hang from Flying Bug blog just posted some other interesting godaddy tweaks and corrected an indentation error in my original post. Much appreciated - go check out his blog as well: https://xiehang.com/blog/2009/07/03/symfony-and-godaddy/ [...]
item.content:encoded: […] Addendum: Hang from Flying Bug blog just posted some other interesting godaddy tweaks and corrected an indentation error in my original post. Much appreciated – go check out his blog as well: https://xiehang.com/blog/2009/07/03/symfony-and-godaddy/ […]

item.title: By: Hang
item.dc:creator: Hang

Found this article from search engine, one of the hotest article from my blog ...
I moved to Amazon AWS several months back (cannot recall the exact date, try search my blog for why, hehe), and I'm going to evaluate Symfony again for a hobby project :-P.
item.content:encoded:
Found this article from search engine, one of the hotest article from my blog …

I moved to Amazon AWS several months back (cannot recall the exact date, try search my blog for why, hehe), and I’m going to evaluate Symfony again for a hobby project :-P.

item.title: By: Hang
item.dc:creator: Hang
item.description:
Guys, I moved to Linode and here is <a href="https://xiehang.com/blog/2011/02/12/godaddy-vs-linode/" rel="nofollow">why</a>, since Linode offer pretty good VPS in a reasonable price, I no longer have to fight with problems coming from shared Web hosting.
However, still thanks everybody here for your comments.
item.content:encoded:
Guys, I moved to Linode and here is why, since Linode offer pretty good VPS in a reasonable price, I no longer have to fight with problems coming from shared Web hosting.

However, still thanks everybody here for your comments.

item.title: By: Irvin Gomez
item.dc:creator: Irvin Gomez
item.description:
Thanks! this post was very helpful, but besides changing factories.yml, I also had to change file extensions on GoDaddy, so .php used PHP 5.x instead of PHP 5.x FastCGI.
I got that hint from the following link: http://cegeekbook.blogspot.com/2010/07/php-no-input-file-specified-godaddy.html
Hope it helps.
item.content:encoded:
Thanks! this post was very helpful, but besides changing factories.yml, I also had to change file extensions on GoDaddy, so .php used PHP 5.x instead of PHP 5.x FastCGI.

I got that hint from the following link:
http://cegeekbook.blogspot.com/2010/07/php-no-input-file-specified-godaddy.html

Hope it helps.

item.title: By: Tiago Carvalho
item.dc:creator: Tiago Carvalho
item.description:
Hi!
Thanks a lot for your tips! It all worked for me except for one thing.. I can access my site through the dev interface (both frontend_dev.php and backend_dev.php). But I can't access it via the production environment... It just keeps returning me a non-symfony "404 page not found" page... I guess it must have to be something in .htaccess.. A
Any ideas?
Thanks in advance!
item.content:encoded:
Hi!

Thanks a lot for your tips! It all worked for me except for one thing.. I can access my site through the dev interface (both frontend_dev.php and backend_dev.php). But I can’t access it via the production environment… It just keeps returning me a non-symfony “404 page not found” page… I guess it must have to be something in .htaccess.. A

Any ideas?

Thanks in advance!

item.title: By: Hang
item.dc:creator: Hang
item.description: I guess the error message from your first problem is misleading - does it mean "you should launch symfony in symfony directory"?
item.content:encoded: I guess the error message from your first problem is misleading – does it mean “you should launch symfony in symfony directory”?

item.title: By: Abhinav
item.dc:creator: Abhinav
item.description:
Hello, and thanks for the help. Actually putting the second fix in seems to be causing the relinking error, and that error goes away when I remove LD_PRELOAD from .bash_profile. However, in both cases, I get this error -
"You must launch symfony command line with the symfony script"
I did a bit of digging, and this is the first fail case message in symfony.php, supposed to be displayed when $sf_lib_dir is not set.
Part two of my deployment headache is that the empty action/module error refuses to go away, even with the REQUEST_URI solution. However, when I check Symfony settings on the error page, I notice that the sf_lib_dir is correctly set.
Any help would be welcome. Thanks
item.content:encoded:
Hello, and thanks for the help. Actually putting the second fix in seems to be causing the relinking error, and that error goes away when I remove LD_PRELOAD from .bash_profile. However, in both cases, I get this error –

“You must launch symfony command line with the symfony script”

I did a bit of digging, and this is the first fail case message in symfony.php, supposed to be displayed when $sf_lib_dir is not set.

Part two of my deployment headache is that the empty action/module error refuses to go away, even with the REQUEST_URI solution. However, when I check Symfony settings on the error page, I notice that the sf_lib_dir is correctly set.

Any help would be welcome. Thanks
